data.title: Looking for a processor to convert 576p to 576i
data.meta_description: I'm looking for a video processor or any device that will convert my Sky box HDMI 576p signal to true 576i and not just re-interlace it. Any suggestions? I...
data.text:

Feb 22, 2016

#1

I'm looking for a video processor or any device that will convert my Sky box HDMI 576p signal to true 576i and not just re-interlace it. Any suggestions? I noticed a thread on this forum that said the DVDO iScan VP50 can do it but that was from 2006. I can't seem to find any recent forum posts about a device that will convert 576p to 576i.

I'm recording old shows that are NOT available on DVD/Bluray such as standup comedy shows. I'm using an Elgato Game Capture HD. It records 1080i perfectly. However the Sky box only outputs 576p via HDMI which gives a juddery framerate. So at the moment I can only get 576i via SCART. I use a high quality fully pinned SCART cable connected to a RGB SCART to S-Video converter box. The S-video goes into the Elgato. For some reason the Elgato adds about 20 pixels of side borders to the left and right of the picture and adds flicker to the top 8 pixels and bottom 4 pixels. I can correct all these problems when re-encoding with Avisynth & cleanup filters but I'd like to avoid the problems in the first place by recording 576i via HDMI as HDMI gives a perfect picture.

Last edited: Feb 22, 2016

There could also be a VP30 edition to. Only came in contact with about 10 of these in total. I do seem to remember these items having this, however I cannot remember if they down sampled or not. It's almost 10 years since I played with one.

DVDO iscan VP30 or a lumagen

Regards, Shane.

Awesome thanks. I'm recording old shows that are NOT available on DVD/Bluray such as standup comedy shows. I'm using an Elgato Game Capture HD. It records 1080i perfectly. However the Sky box only outputs 576p via HDMI which gives a juddery framerate. So at the moment I can only get 576i via SCART. I use a high quality fully pinned SCART cable connected to a RGB SCART to S-Video converter box. The S-video goes into the Elgato. For some reason the Elgato adds about 20 pixels of side borders to the left and right of the picture and adds flicker to the top 8 pixels and bottom 4 pixels. I can correct all these problems when re-encoding with Avisynth & cleanup filters but I'd like to avoid the problems in the first place by recording 576i via HDMI as HDMI gives a perfect picture.

Could you please set your Sky box to automatic resolution and play an SD channel such as Challenge. If you press the info button on your TV remote it should say the picture is 576p. Could you please connect each of your processors to your Sky box via HDMI and set the resolution on the processor to 576i. Does your TV now say it's outputting 576i?

I dont have a sky box, but i can take a DVD player and feed the scaler 576P and output 576i to my oppo 103D and checkthe format, or use the Lumagen radiance, but if the DVDO vp50 say its 576 out, its 576i out, i dont doubt much about that, and that will be with standard timings.

The judder your talking about sounds like you have the framerate converted somewhere, is it possible you are running 576P 60hz.? I know tv productions can be a huge mess of framerates, so its important to know the native framerate, wich might be 24, 25 30 50 or 60hz for PAL formats ill guess they stick to 25 and 50hz

#6

The Sky box juddery framerate happens because it's converting 576i 25fps to 576p 25fps instead of doubling the frame rate.

Does your DVD player only output 576p 25fps via HDMI? If so then do you have any video you can play on it that was NOT shot on film and is 576i? You should then be able to see the unsmooth framerate if your DVD player is playing it in 576p 25fps. Can you then try using your DVDO vp50 to output 576i from your DVD player. Does it play smoothly? If so then it sounds like the DVDO vp50 is doing what I want it to do.

I dont understand why deinterlacing should add judder, frame doubling should not change that, it normaly only happens if you have a odd framerate convertion.

Is it possible that your monitor cant display 25hz, and converts it to something else, what monitor are you using.?

#8

I dont understand why deinterlacing should add judder, frame doubling should not change that, it normaly only happens if you have a odd framerate convertion.

Yes but if you look at what I said, the Sky box is NOT frame doubling. So it's not converting 25fps to 50fps. It's just converting the 576i 25fps picture to 576p 25fps which means the framerate is no longer smooth as you lose half the temporal resolution. I have my Sky box connected to my TV not a monitor.

You said your DVD player can only output 576p 50hz. That just means it's PAL. I'm assuming it's 576p 25fps? If so then that's good so we can see if your DVDO VP50 is able to give a 576i signal from your player, can you please try what I said in post 6.

The monitors have a internal frequence, so some monitors will take any input framerate, and display them at some fixed framerate like 96hz so the internal processing in the monitor is kind of important when talking about judder.

Now i just hooked up the VP30 and it wont output 576i, it starts at 480P and up, might be able to select a 1080i and customise it to 576i.

Now i can unlock the framerate and output 575P 25hz, and try feed my oppo 103, and see how that turns out if its set to output 576i 50hz

#17

The Sky box juddery framerate happens because it's converting 576i 25fps to 576p 25fps instead of doubling the frame rate.

I don't know if you just wrote it backwards but it's i that should have the doubled framerate, 50fps i = 25fps p. If you convert from i to p you should halve the framerate, not double.

Feb 23, 2016

#18

Please stop using the "fps" term incorrectly, it just confuses people! I said 576i 25fps meaning frames per second which is the same as 50i (50 fields per second). 576i doesn't have 50 frames per second, it has 25 frames per second. Converting from interlaced to progressive does NOT give you half the framerate, it gives you the same frame rate but you lose half the temporal resolution (you lose half the motion) which causes the framerate to look unsmooth.

If you want a smooth framerate you have to double the frame rate from 25 fps to 50fps.

#19

I don't think what you want to do is entirely possible from an HD box. You can't guarantee what the Sky box has done to the signal to turn it into 576P (bob/weave/motion adaptive), so you won't always be able to get back to the exact interlaced fields. Anything you do will be the best guess of a scaler re-interlacing. DVDO Iscan Duo has PreP which attempts to revert the progressive image to its interlaced fields intelligently for reprocessing (undoing sub-optimal deinterlacing, supposedly), but these kind of things can never be perfect.

"Back in the day" the best option was to have a modified Sky box with an SDI digital output, and capture off that. But I guess your issue is that the content is already recorded onto the HD box?

If you are able to re-record your content, an SDI Sky box with SDI capture card would be the best option for accuracy. Not cheap, mind.

Sky+ with SDI

SweetSpot SDI
